abstract.text: Apply textures to the surface of your scene’s 3D objects to give each object a unique appearance.

inlineContent.text: Materials define the appearance of 3D models in RealityKit, by defining how their surfaces interact with light. Materials can also occlude objects behind them, hold shaders, or act as portals to view other worlds with
RealityKit includes a few material types to help you get started, including
for basic color and textures, and
for realistic lighting effects such as reflections, roughness, and emission.

abstract.text: A container for resources that will be encoded into a CustomMaterial’s custom uniforms argument buffer.
The abstract superclass for objects representing compute functions for RealityKit custom materials .
An object that defines the roughness of an entity’s surface.
An alias for the cull mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.
Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
An alias for the cull mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.
An object that you use to configure new
objects.
A component that defines a portal world.
An object that specifies an entity’s normal map.
An invisible material that hides objects rendered behind it.
The type of object used to control the removal of polygons that aren’t
visible to the user.
Describes the texture managed by the drawable queue
An object that defines the specular highlights of an entity.
The scalar parameter applied to a material.
An alias for the face culling object that’s appropriate for this
material class.
An object that defines the degree to which an entity reflects light to
create stretched or oblong highlights.
A container for texture data allowing you to create and update textures using your own format.
An object that defines the color of the light an entity emits.

abstract.text: Create a more immersive experience by adding video reflections in a custom environment.

strokes by integrating RealityKit with ARKit and SwiftUI.
